_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Whiting Terminal & Storage
RMP Executive Summary

At the Enterprise Whiting Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.

The Enterprise Whiting Terminal and Storage is owned by Enterprise Terminal & Storage, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC and operated by Enterprise Products Operating LLC.  .This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Whiting Terminal that are regulated by EPA?s RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Whiting Terminal is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pipeline facility as well as a propane storage and loading facility.  The process is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.

The Whiting Terminal has two Department of Transportation regulated pipelines that are routed through the facility.  These two pipelines are a mixed natural gas liquids line (natural gasoline, naphtha, normal butane, iso-butane and propane) and a dedicated natural gas liquids (propane) pipeline.  These pipelines have pumps that are driven by gas turbines, which can add horsepower to

continue the product transfer down the pipelines, or the pump system can be bypassed.  In addition there is one pipeline leg that comes off the dedicated propane pipeline and is the propane product supply line to the Enterprise Ogden Terminal and Storage facility.   The Whiting facility also receives propane from one of the two natural gas liquids pipelines to a single 90,000 gallon capacity storage tank.  This tank is used for storage and distribution to the two truck transport loading docks which also have capabilities to stench the propane for retail sales companies. The single propane storage tank is administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 80% of their capacity.

In our process we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

No toxic chemicals are handled or used at the Enterprise Whiting terminal.

Flammables

Propane is a finished product which can be delivered into the single storage tank via the dedicated propane pipeline or the mixed product pipeline.  This material is routed from the tank to the truck transport loading docks for wholesale distribution to propane retailers.  A small quantity of Ethyl Mercaptan is used to stench the propane at the truck transport docks.  However, the Ethyl Mercaptan present at the Whiting terminal is stored in a maximum quantity below the threshold quantity in the Risk Management Program rule.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenario and alternative release scenario for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.

Worst Case Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no regulated toxic chemicals present at the Enterprise Wh

iting terminal.

Alternate Release Scenario(s) ? Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no regulated toxic chemicals present at the Enterprise Whiting terminal.

Worse Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This simulation involves the rupture or failure of the propane storage tank resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  The entire inventory of the tank is simulated in the release as required by the RMP regulation.  This scenario assumes there would be no mitigation of the flammable propane release.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the worst case scenario reporting section  of the Risk Management Plan registration.

Alternate Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 500 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the line break.  The simulation calculated that 21,150 pounds of material would be released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  These measures consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the alternate case scenario section of the Risk Management Plan re

gistration.

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Monona County Sheriff?s Department Emergency Management District, which includes the local Whiting Police Department, Monona County Sheriff?s Department, Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Monona County Sheriff?s Department and local Fire Departments.  Remote activation can also be accomplished from Houston Control which has area video cameras with dial-up access.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shutdown remotely from Houston Control or locally by operations personnel.  A third party contractor, 3E Company is under contract to contact the necessary agencies if required.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management

of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As a part of the prevention efforts, there are a number of programs in which Enterprise employees participate.  A training program has been developed in which Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.

Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release within the last five years..

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Facility safety is a primary goal at Enterpirse.  The Whiting Terminal promptly addesses safety recommendations from process hazard analyses conducted at the facility.  Safety management program improvements recommended as a result of internal facility prog

ram audits are also acted upon to insure prompt correction.  Safety recommendations made by location employees are considered and implemented if the proposal can be shown to improve facility safety.  The facility safety management (PSM) system is reviewed on a continuing basis with the goal of an improved safety program and a safe facility as a result.  At this time, there are no projects planned for installation at Whiting Terminal that will result in improving the safety of the facility.
